newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait jumbo loan payments on schedule - bank.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait jumbo loan payments on schedule - bank.

text.p: Kuwait is on schedule in paying off a $5.5 billion sovereign loan and the outstanding principal of $1.57 billion is expected to be cleared by the end of 1996, the country's largest commercial bank said on Wednesday.

"The oustanding principal balance is now $1.57 billion, which should be fully repaid with the remaining two instalments scheduled for September and December of this year," National Bank of Kuwait said in a quarterly economic review.

The Kuwaiti government borrowed the money to help pay costs of reconstruction following Iraq's 1990-91 occupation. By mid-1995 Kuwait had paid about $1 billion in interest on the facility, analysts say.

At that time the loan, arranged by J.P. Morgan and Co , was the largest ever made to a sovereign state. The main lending banks came from five main markets -- Japan, France, Germany, the United States and Arab countries.
Kuwait's Central Bank Governor, Sheikh Salem Abdul-Aziz al-Sabah, was quoted by state-owned Kuwait News Agency in October 1995 as saying Kuwait would not borrow from the international markets again.
